user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_flush:
```c
static int lfs_file_flush(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_READING) {
        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &file->cache);
        }
        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_READING;
    }

#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_WRITING) {
        lfs_off_t pos = file->pos;

        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            // copy over anything after current branch
            lfs_file_t orig = {
                .ctz.head = file->ctz.head,
                .ctz.size = file->ctz.size,
                .flags = LFS_O_RDONLY,
                .pos = file->pos,
                .cache = lfs->rcache,
            };
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &lfs->rcache);

            while (file->pos < file->ctz.size) {
                // copy over a byte at a time, leave it up to caching
                // to make this efficient
                uint8_t data;
                lfs_ssize_t res = lfs_file_flushedread(lfs, &orig, &data, 1);
                if (res < 0) {
                    return res;
                }

                res = lfs_file_flushedwrite(lfs, file, &data, 1);
                if (res < 0) {
                    return res;
                }

                // keep our reference to the rcache in sync
                if (lfs->rcache.block != LFS_BLOCK_NULL) {
                    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &orig.cache);
                    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &lfs->rcache);
                }
            }

            // write out what we have
            while (true) {
                int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, &file->cache, &lfs->rcache, true);
                if (err) {
                    if (err == LFS_ERR_CORRUPT) {
                        goto relocate;
                    }
                    return err;
                }

                break;

relocate:
                LFS_DEBUG("Bad block at 0x%"PRIx32, file->block);
                err = lfs_file_relocate(lfs, file);
                if (err) {
                    return err;
                }
            }
        } else {
            file->pos = lfs_max(file->pos, file->ctz.size);
        }

        // actual file updates
        file->ctz.head = file->block;
        file->ctz.size = file->pos;
        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_WRITING;
        file->flags |= LFS_F_DIRTY;

        file->pos = pos;
    }
#endif

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no pointer declarations in this function that appear to be non-const when they could (MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13). Reasoning for not flagging any fragments:

- Function parameters: lfs_t *lfs and lfs_file_t *file are both used to modify state inside the function (file->flags, file->pos, file->ctz, and operations that alter lfs->rcache and caches). Therefore they cannot be const-qualified.

- Local object orig is an lfs_file_t value (not a pointer). Its .cache field and other members are used and modified (lfs_cache_drop is later called on &orig.cache), so orig cannot be const.

- Addresses taken and passed to helper functions (e.g., &file->cache, &lfs->rcache, &orig.cache, &data) are used by those helpers to modify caches or to provide a destination buffer for reads. These uses require mutable targets, so they should not be const.

- Passing &data to the write function is acceptable even if that function takes a pointer-to-const for the buffer parameter; that would be a compatibility of passing a mutable object to a const parameter and does not violate 8.13 in this translation unit.

Given each pointer usage is either modified directly in this function or is passed to callees that plausibly modify the pointed-to data (or are used as output buffers), there are no obvious places in this snippet where pointers should be changed to point to const-qualified types.
